response.answer_text: Of course! So long as that freedom is in the political and/or economic interests of the United States. Which, in many cases, it is. “Freedom” usually implies freedom to do business with US corporations, the “freedom” to provide support to US military and political operations in the region, and “freedom” to accept US culture which foster favorable views of America. Those are the kinds of freedoms that the US heartily promotes. That said, there have been many instances where freedom hasn’t really been in the US’s interest. And lo and behold, in those cases we support some rather brutal dictators — from the Shah of Iran to Noriega to the Saudi royal family. The United States government has one job, which is to protect the interests of the United States and its people. Expecting anything else is naive. That should be obvious. Yet it’s strange that so many Americans think of the USA as some sort of global superhero, doing good and battling evil around the world. LOL, no. They are only the heroes in their own own story. But it seems for many Americans it’s the only story they ever hear.

Fuck no. Sorry to be SO blunt. But there is very little freedom in the USA, it is all a big, fat lie that Hollywood would have you believe. I am American and have lived outside of the USA for the better part of 6 years. I have found BY FAR more freedom and life enjoyment in other countries than I EVER did in the USA, with its high exorbitant costs of everything and super restrictive laws. Don’t get me wrong. I LOVE my country. But I don’t want to live there anymore. As far as “providing freedom” via the war machine, I believe that it is all a big hoax to take over regions, keep regions unstable in order to profit from oil for the biggest evil corporations on Earth. They provide nothing but headaches in places like Iraq. But I don’t live there and don’t now what it is like for the Iraqi people after having been given their “freedom” from the US govt and military. I do believe that this freedom cost the Iraqi people their health, many beautiful museums, houses, dignity and sense of peace. All because the USA “had to” take out an evil dictator that was put into place in the first place by … guess who?! The US GOVT! There is no respect for life, people, property when it comes to the US GOVT. Have they caused more freedom for anyone, anywhere, because they exist? Hell no.

I guess we should define freedom, just to be on the same page. Freedom, from the US point of view, can be defined as a country that uses the same economic system of the United States and is beholding to the United States. If a country uses a different kind of economic system then it needs to be “freed” and if it can’t be persuaded to change its economic system then it will be “forced” to be free. Sometimes a country is freed by the CIA and sometimes by a military invasion.Yes, the US does play a big role in freedom.

In the ranking of countries, the United States is not even in the top 10 countries for freedom. We talk about freedom, and at one time we were the freest country. We were truly the land of the free. That is no longer the case. Now it is just a talking point so that we can apply political pressure on other countries. Look at the two major political parties. The Democrats are worse than Republicans, however both of them want to pass all kinds of laws to restrict all kinds of things for us. The Democrats have been pushing to prohibit smoking, and food that they feel like is not really good for us. The Republicans are just as bad in some of the things that they want to prohibit. To be the land of the free, people need to quit prohibiting things.

I would give a strong yes. The United States is about the only country in the world which gives full respect to the freedom of speech. If you disagree then I dare you to offer a harsh criticism of a non-Christian religion in the EU, use biological rather than psychological gender pronouns in Canada or be openly pro-Gay in much of the Islamic world. In those countries these actions can at least in theory result in official sanction. Not in the U.S.. With out freedom of speech there can not be an open flow of thoughts and ideas. People are not allowed to have full control of their own minds. I would argue control of one's own mind is the most fundamental freedom of them all.

Probably as big a role as the US have played against freedom. Let’s just say that the United States’ track record as regards the freedom of antions and peoples has not been unblemished. But there’s another side to this question. ‘Freedom’ is also a slogan. And in that sense the US have played - willingly, nillingly - a substantial part. And it’s in thsis ense that people often think of the US. But there’s two sides to the coin.

Yes, of course it does. Both through the example that it exhibits to the entire world and has for 240 years, Along with the direct intervention as it is taken in World War I, World War II, and the Cold War, As well as diplomatic and economic pressure can bring to bear on totalitarian more authoritarian regimes, In through simple moral example, yes, the United States exerts great influence in half and direct power in preserving or promoting freedom globally.

Inasmuch as some people want to continue living under our Constitution, with its unique promise of a nation under God, for the people and by the people, yes. Has American hegemony created problems in the world since WW II? Yes. Is life confusing and are there contradictions? You bet.

As the most powerful and largest free nation on Earth we play a tremendous role in promoting the cause of democratic based government by the people and for the people. When the people control their governments there is peace when governments control their people there is war. When was the last time a democratic government declared war on another democratic government?
The US is the poster child for freedom which is why much of the population wants to see most of the previous several administrations enjoy the rest of their short and pathetic little lives at GITMO.
